title: Physics-Informed Neural Networks for Transonic Flows around an Airfoil
authors: Simon Wassing, Stefan Langer, Philipp Bekemeyer
abstract:
Physics-informed neural networks have gained popularity as a deep-learning
based method for solving problems governed by partial differential equations.
Especially for engineering applications, this new method seems to be promising
since it can solve parametric problems. Therefore, a single neural network
could substitute many classical simulations in parameter studies. The
simulation of inviscid, compressible flows around an airfoil, has been a
challenging task for classical numerical methods for many decades and is
relevant for industrial applications to this day. Only recently, researchers
have been able to successfully simulate subsonic flows around an airfoil with
physics-informed neural networks by utilizing mesh transformations to
precondition the optimization problem that needs to be solved. Here, we extend
this methodology into the transonic regime. Previous attempts showed
difficulties to capture the normal shock waves that occur at these flow
conditions. Inspired by classical numerical methods, we introduce an analytic
sensor function that locally introduces artificial viscosity at the shock
locations to stabilize the training process. We validate the method at
different transonic flow conditions for the NACA0012 airfoil, obtaining errors
of less than one percent, compared to finite volume simulations. In addition we
show how a parametric model can approximate the solution in a continuous range
of angle of attacks. The presented method could help to pave the way for
physics-informed neural networks towards industrial applications in
aerodynamics.
